My guess is that this is caused by the zip uploader not extracting filename correctly. My guess is that it's looking for "/" and so is confused by Windows-style "\" delimiters. Going to confirm now...
Actually ... on second thoughts, I now think it's probably the Flash uploader.

Here's Alex's upload:
[26-Mar-2010 10:33:08] [abrown@new2012]
<uploadAsset id="11">
  <parameters>
    tags = null
    name = C:\Documents and Settings\Alexandra.Brown\Desktop\olympic_stadium_lights_500x248
    section = Images/Olympic Park
  </parameters>
  filename  = olympic_stadium_lights_500x248.jpg
  type      = image/pjpeg
  file size = 65367
</uploadAsset>

And here's one from someone else:
[26-Mar-2010 10:39:47] [uzma.khan@new2012]
<uploadAsset id="13">
  <parameters>
    Upload = Submit Query
    name = 100322_ODA_MDA_AC_023_HI[1]
    Filename = 100322_ODA_MDA_AC_023_HI[1].JPG
    section = Images/Video
    unpack = false
  </parameters>
  filename  = 100322_ODA_MDA_AC_023_HI[1].JPG
  type      = image/jpeg
  file size = 6949596
</uploadAsset>

My guess is that Alex is using the Flash uploader, but that Uzma is NOT.

I can't use the Flash uploader in Linux, and Alex is obv. using Windows.

Will reboot into Windows and see what I can see...

Assigning to Janos, but am taking a quick look now, in case I spot anything.

Alex, I've been struggling to reproduce this. Can you let me know which browser version you are using please? And also which version of the Flash plugin you have?

Browser version can be ascertained by clicking on "Help->About".

Flash version can be ascertained by visiting: http://www.adobe.com/software/flash/about/ (and looking for the box that says: "Version information".

Also, can you tell me how you uploaded the image? Was it while you were editing a page?

Thanks,
Kieran

Hello Alex,
Yes it is related to using using the simple uploader.
When you choose the file, the "name" field gets auto-populated with the name of the file. However, for some reason, in IE7, the rest of the file path also appears.
Can I ask you, for the time being, to manually remove the path (as per the screenshot I'm sending).
In the meantime, though, we will fix this bug.
Kieran

Assigning to Janos:
Here's the problem:
 http://dev.kitsite.com/kit/file-input.html
It means that:
 dialogs/simple-upload.jsp
needs fixing:
 var name = $('file').value, ext;
needs to be amended to work in IE7.
I think that ".value" SHOULD just return the file's name, and not the path. I may be wrong on this presumption though.
Whatever the case is though, the path needs to be removed by the simple upload tool.
Hope this makes sense.
Kieran

Sorry, Alex the above comment was supposed to be internal! I don't want to confuse you, so please just ignore it and read the comment ABOVE that one.
Thanks! Kieran

comments.value:
Hi Danny,

Can you please give me a call to discuss this?

Thanks,
Lakshmi

As discussed, we will analyse the logs from our end and send the information on user agents, actual website referrers, etc to you regularly. However, we need to understand how you would want us to send this information to you. Will it be through emails?

Thanks,
Lakshmi

Danny,

Not replying directly ;-) for fear of getting sucked in, but...

It probably enough to parse the logs on web01 and out the output the results as a HTML page inside a password protected dir (*) under the doc root ie. /www/html/new/london2012/404report/ 

As for the report itself, would be good to separate out:

- Direct 404 requests : these are outside our control
- Requests form robots:  also outside our control
- 404 with referring pages that we serve (ie. broken links on our pages) : these we /can/ do something about
- But excluded from the above should be any requests from the 'lookahead engine' of the buggy version of IE8 (or similar). 

In short the list of errors should be pretty small and limited to one we can actually fix ie. broken links in web pages we are serving. No harm in listing the rest but these should be separated out as they are outside of our control.

The point of this file is we can easily spot any error or broken link introduced into the site, a huge list of vague 404's is near useless, with or without referrers/agents (or at the very least will require a lot of manual effort to digest / investigate each time we look at it)

* a .htaccess file with the following in it will do the trick: (login/pass is any previous 2012 password combination ie. stratford/design or you could add new entry to /var/www/.htpasswd)

AuthName "Restricted Area New"
AuthType Basic
AuthUserFile /var/www/.htpasswd
AuthGroupFile /dev/null
require valid-user

We will take the report in whatever form is easiest for you send. Email is fine. Another possibility is to output the results as a HTML page inside a password protected directory on the site.

As for the report itself, it would be good to separate out:

- Direct 404 requests
- Requests from robots
- Requests from the 'lookahead engine' of the buggy version of IE8
- 404s with referring pages that we serve (ie. broken links on our pages)

The first three we cannot do much about, so although it would be useful to get some numbers, it is probably less useful to get a detailed breakdown.

The 404s originating from within the site (but excluding buggy IE8 requests) are the ones that we can and should fix, so for these we would want more detail.
Closing this one.

Is it possible to do a form on the website where people fill in details about their business/answer questions and they get a response/outcome automatically?
 
This is something we may potentially need on the website in September (along with new templates from Cogapp for the Travel portal which Morag has told you about) but first I need to know if this is possible?
 
We would obviously have several pre-written outcomes/links to information which would be the end result depending on what information the user fills in.
Certainly this is possible. When you are ready, it would be very useful if you could put together an outline of what's required so we can respond in a bit more detail.
Closing this.

I think it's now for Deepak and Jamie Unwin at Kitsite to pick this up.

I am confused as to why this problem has arisen again, when we thought we'd solved this a few weeks ago. It suggests that some change has been made or a virus introduced since then which has  created this problem - would be good to pinpoint what and when.

According to Femi, the emails sent on behalf of gamesmaker.london2012.com come from the Atos solution.  The london2012.com domain has been delegated to the email server that sends emails via the accessibility form - so more than likely, 213.120.228.150 belongs to BT but this needs confirmation.



>> BT (this needs to be routed to BT via Servicedesk) : Can BT please check if this is the external IP address they own?



>> KitSite (Developers managing the accessibility form solution): As this issue involves the accessibility form, can you ensure the email is formed correctly?  In some cases, a malformed email arising from an incorrectly populated form has been known to be flagged as a Trojan/virus.

Deepak, can you:

a) liaise with KitSite/BT if need be.

b) engage with BT (if they own the email server which is sending these emails out) as necessary - copy emails to all cc'd above.



Thanks

comments.value: Provisional date.
We would like to move this date back. We need access to an Omnia 2 to start work on this.

Can I just confirm, are we still wanting to target the Omnia 2? The new Samsung Galaxy is Android based and according to recent news reports Samsung are now pushing their Android smart phones ahead of the Windows-based phones like the Omnia.
Checking and will come back to you asap
Our view is that the Omnia is yesterday’s phone and the Galaxy/Android phones are the more important from the Samsung point of view – so better to focus on those.

This is very good news. This essentially means we are targeting the same webkit browser engine as the iPhone. I will mark this as solved, but there is a related ticket which we will be returning to shortly: http://postcms.zendesk.com/tickets/437

Morag, have you ever seen this problem again?

I've spent some time trying to figure out what's going on - and starting to believe it's a crossdomain.xml issue, or in English: a flash issue. I can spend more time trying to pinpoint the problem, but it's very time consuming, and may end up having to change the swf. Probably those who produced the flash file could sort this out much quicker than we do.

Details: flash is very restrictive about fetching data from different subdomains - and in webcams there are quite a few subdomains are involved:

- the page itself on "london2012.com" (or www.london2012.com)
- the webcam flash is located at "map.london2012.com"
- the csv file containing the different webcam picture filenames is located "webcams.map.london2012.com"
- the pictures are at "cloudfront.webcams.map.london2012.com"

If for some reason any of the rights aren't right (for caching or different reasons), the page doesn't load properly.

Are you therefore still investigating how to fix it?

 

Liz Goulding

New Media Producer

London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games

Direct line: +44 (0) 203 2012 297

Switchboard: +44 (0) 203 2012 000

www.london2012.com  

www.twitter.com/london2012 

________________________________

To reiterate, what Janos said, "it's a crossdomain.xml issue, or in English: a flash issue. I can spend more time trying to pinpoint the problem, but it's very time consuming, and may end up having to change the swf. Probably those who produced the flash file could sort this out much quicker than we do."

In other words, he can spend more time on it, but it may be quite a lot of time (a day or two, rather than an hour or two) and it may lead him to the same conclusion, i.e. the flash file needs to be tweaked.

It may be sensible to forward his comments to Stamen for their feedback. If his diagnosis is correct, then they may be a better position than us to fix the issue.

This is what Stamen said:

 

"I had a chance to look at this today, and it's not a Flash
_permissions_ problem. We've ensure that all of the domains from which
we're loading data have a permissive crossdomain.xml.

 

I went back and looked at the dates that Finn originally reported as
broken, but unfortunately we only load up the last year of hourly photos
so I can't check January through March of 2009 anymore. However, we do
appear to be missing May, 2009 through January, 2010:

 

Liz Goulding

www.london2012.com  

www.twitter.com/london2012

Liz, would you like us to take another look at this and do you want us to put an upper limit on how much time we spend investigating?

Well, given that it's a bug, it needs to be fixed. Take a look again,
please. Maybe for an hour and see what you find.

 

Liz Goulding

Direct line: +44 (0) 203 2012 297

looking into it again atm.

This is interesting. If you have a look at http://stack.tjp.hu/o.html there's two flash things embedded there, the webcam and the 2012 logo. We've checked on several browsers, and the ones that are having problems with the webcams are all fine with the logo. The markup is exactly the same, the only thing that differs is the source swf.

I think this is a complex issue, but based on this experiment, it looks like it's at least partly a problem w/ the flash. We're thinking it may or may not be connected with ones hosts settings too.

If I copy/paste your note and send it to Stamen, will it make sense to them?

comments.value:
Hi guys,

Something totally new!

Just following up on some usability feedback from our testing in the winter/spring.

One idea was to animate the 5 promo pictures on the homepage so that they scroll through all of them.  Also included in this idea was replacing the 1-5 blue buttons with thumbnails (obviously they'd need to be slightly larger).  Without us going off and getting the thing redesigned, do you think this is something you could do?  Give it some thought (and a quote) and we can try and figure out how to go forward!

Liz

Liz Goulding
New Media Producer
London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games
Direct line: +44 (0) 203 2012 297
Switchboard: +44 (0) 203 2012 000
www.london2012.com
www.twitter.com/london2012
Priority set to high (so that it gets out attention).

Liz,

Rather than thumbnails (unless I am missing something we are very tight on space there) how about as we automatically scroll though the images, get the text and the relevant blue box to highlight.

On top of that what about making the boxes more arrow like, so that it highlights a natural flow, although there is a danger that it will be to indicative of a 'steps' and dissuade people from missing a step. Trying to find an example but will give it a go in words first in case you go "Oh I know what you mean" ;-) Basically change the background of each [number] so that it becomes a interlocked arrow with the next box.

Jamie

Hmm. I agree on the space issue. One thought we had was to arrange the thumbnails vertically, rather than horizontally, but that’s a bit more design work. The idea was that the thumbnails actually indicate there are more photos coming rather than blue boxes.

That said, I like the idea of a ‘natural flow’ so long as people don’t take it too literally and thing that they are sequential (they’re not).

I’m thinking that we’re probably safer if we do some mock-ups, as I reckon we’ll need a ‘pause’ button, too, for accessibility reasons.
I certainly think we need some mockups first, will get the paint box out later...

Liz,

Jamie was suggesting let's try something light'n'subtle with the current homepage keeping your aims in sight:
http://new2012.kitsite.com/kit/preview/index.php

Here's what it does:
- the numbers are changing on hover, there's a little border (inviting for action)
- also, there's a tooltip with the article title on the numbers
- if no one is doing anything (and the cursor is not in the area), it automatically goes around the banners (one step in 10 seconds)

This is ready to go live now.

Wrt the new homepage, Jamie suggested http://www.timeout.com/ with a very nice and usable carousel, but I'm more than happy to have a look around and shop for different solutions so when it comes to designing, we'll have a good idea where to go.
I think it looks like a great first step, at least. Let me get some feedback from the rest of the team before we go live!

I'm wondering if there's final thumbs-up w/ this. Jamie says you're happy with the webcam changes, but waiting for approvals, and you have some accessibility concerns about the header changer. I did some research - here are the results:

- The carousel is updating very slowly, once in every 30 seconds - The likelihood of this causing any accessibility issues is very low.
- We could introduce a pause button - which make the ui more confusing as the page is almost static. I'd strongly advise against this.
- We could add some clever logic to figure if the user is a screen reader user or not - this would involve some extra work, and I doubt it's strictly necessary to meet accessibility guidelines, but if you want to be 110% sure, I'm more than happy to add it.

Either way, would be great if we could get this (and the webcam story as well) sorted by the end of the day :)

Sorry Janos – not quite good to go. But I’m aware of the pressure of the ‘technology freeze’ if that’s why you are eager to get it sorted?

For the webcams – how difficult would it be for us to choose which webcam went up every day – or at least manually override it if we happened to randomly get one that was down that day (apparently it happens)? If we can get reassurance on that, I think we’d be ok.

Fir the carousel – can we mimic the functionality here: http://www.london2012.com/get-involved/volunteer/index.php then I think we’d be ok Accessibility-wise.
Then pause button it is. Should take a bit of extra time to make it fit next to the 1-5 buttons, but shouldn't be much more than a day altogether. Trying to clean this up asap.
Cool. And is the highlighted button now pink (in line with the photos/volunteer landing page)
Looking now.

http://new2012.kitsite.com/kit/preview/index.php
play-pause monster is in preview now - ready to be published.
Looks fantastic! How long is the delay between pictures? My instinct is to speed it up a smidge...

10 seconds at the moment.
I'd rather not push it live at 6 - first thing tomorrow.
Can we make it 7 seconds transition before we push live? But then yes, go ahead.
it's live!
It’s not really fitting properly, Janos! The pause button has gone down a line. (take a look at it in firefox ... my IE on my main computer hasn’t gotten the published version yet).
And the highlighted number isn’t pink!!
AND the pause button only slows it down – it doesn’t stop it!
Ha, that was weird - it seems syncing happened very-very slowly this time, but now all my browsers show the most recent version.
Ah! That looks better.
But. The pause button still doesn’t actually pause?
Righto – i think it’s pausing, but where you are in the 1-5 rectangles isn’t staying highlighted!
Should stay pink now.
Thank you!
Marking as solved.
